thread.title: GDP growth weakest in two years
thread.title_full: GDP growth weakest in two years

title: GDP growth weakest in two years
text:
Wed, Sep 2, 2015, 12:58 PM AEST - Australia Markets close in 3 hrs 2 mins GDP growth weakest in two years AAP – 16 minutes ago Print 
Economic growth has slowed to its weakest pace in more than two years, dragged down by the sluggish mining and resources sector. 
Australia's economy grew by a weaker-than-expected 0.2 per cent in the June quarter, down from 0.9 per cent in the previous three months. 
While the economy has now notched up its 24th year of growth, the last time it expanded at such a slow pace on a quarterly basis was in the first three months of 2013. 
Economists had expected growth to be about 0.5 per cent during the June quarter, according to an AAP survey. 
On an annual basis, growth came in at 2.0 per cent for the year to June 30, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) said on Wednesday. 
The Australian dollar plunged to a six-year low of 69.89 US cents when the GDP figures were released at 1130 AEST. 
Macquarie senior economist James McIntyre said falling commodity prices had dented economic growth. 
"The world is giving us a pay cut and it means the amount of income the economy is getting is declining," he said. 
"That reflects that hit from commodity prices and that hit has been translating all the way through the economy." 
Mr McIntyre is sticking to his forecast for a November interest rate cut from the Reserve Bank. 
"What we're seeing across the economy from the income side means that we'll just get enough to see a (growth forecast) downgrade that would give the RBA the case to cut," he said. 
Westpac chief currency strategist Robert Rennie said a fall in the number of mines and resources projects being built also dragged down growth during the quarter. 
"Clearly the downside surprise in the headline data seems to be mostly coming from engineering construction," he said. 
Mr Rennie said a 3.4 per cent fall in Australia's terms of trade - the price of exports relative to the price of imports - was a large hit to national income. 
"That hits domestic income, it hits GDP, that obviously is the key driver," he said. 
"It's a weak piece of data, and it's one that should probably see the Australian dollar spend some time trading below the 70 US cent level." @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Growth in line with budget: Hockey AAP 
Treasurer Joe Hockey insists the latest growth figures are in line with his budget forecasts and come at a time …
